text: now people in the UK indeed across the
world will be living with coronavirus
for a very long time according to some
of the UK's leading scientists giving
evidence to MPs today among them
professor Chris witty England's chief
medical officer who defended his advice
to the government on tackling the
pandemic saying that mass testing had to
be abandoned because of capacity issues
I'd also defended the timing of lockdown
the latest figures from the office for
national statistics show that
coronavirus deaths in the week ending on
10th of July fell by almost one third
from the previous week in England Wales
and deaths remained below the number
usually expected at this time of year
for the fourth week in a row today's
latest figures show that a hundred and
ten deaths were recorded in the UK in
the latest 24 hour period our health
editor Huw Pym has the latest including
today's parliamentary exchanges with the
scientists moving on
people adjusting to life with fewer
restrictions but still there are many
questions about government policy at the
start of the coronavirus crisis first
was locked down too late streets emptied
on March the 23rd when the full set of
measures was introduced some of argued
it should have happened a week earlier
when only a partial lockdown message was
used MPs pressed the chief medical
adviser hard on what he said at the time
I had to go through all my MPs wanted to
know what the Sage Committee of advisers
was telling ministers were they
following your advice ministers at the
time who were putting an incredibly
difficult position in my view follow the
advice given by Sage which are clearly
signposted through the minutes of Sage
at with a delay that was no more than
you would reasonably expect for what are
really very difficult things to
operationalize and decide so was testing
too slow there's widespread capacity now
but in March community testing was on a
much smaller scale and was
controversially halted
we had no capacity to do it on the scale
that would have been needed for the kind
of epidemic we had and this hangs your
theory this is a but we've got it up in
four weeks in April we got the test
capacity up to 100,000 a day in just
four weeks so if you devised doing that
in January we could have got to that
stage by the end of February so stage
was consistent and I was consistent in
saying we needed considerably more
testing capacity many of the problems we
had came out of our lack of testing
capacity so some tough questioning there
for Chris witty over decisions affecting
everyone's lives made back in March and
they'll be continuing scrutiny of what
ministers and officials were doing and
saying at the time today's hearing also
looked at where things might go from
here how long will the virus be with us
one sage member said forget the idea it
would fade away soon things will not be
done by Christmas this infection is not
going away it's now a human endemic
infection and even actually if we have a
vaccine or very good treatments humanity
will still be living with this virus for
very many many years to come as for the
vaccine one government advisor said he
was cautiously optimistic it would be in
place by Christmas Hugh Pym BBC News
